questiontext.text:
For passing the theory driving exam, some learning styles are more successful than others. In research on the influence of learning styles on exam results, a separate test has been developed for each learning style. Two test developers talk to each other about the meaning of measurement error \(E\) within classical test theory.

Evaluate the following two statements:

I. The measurement error E of a test does not correlate (\(r_{ET} = 0\)) with the true score \(T\). II. Between the measurement errors \(E\) of the tests for the different learning styles is not consistent.

generalfeedback.text:
Theorem 1: According to classical test theory, measurement error is \(E\) independent of the true score \(T\), because \(E\) is an accidental and unsystematic measurement error.

Theorem 2: Measurement error \(E\) is accidental and unsystematic; there is no consistency among them.

answer.text: Pronunciation I and II are both correct.
Pronunciation I and II are both incorrect.
